column1: Kenner (historically French: Cannes-Brûlées) is the seventh-largest city in the U.S. State of Louisiana following New Orleans
column2: Baton Rouge
column3: Shreveport
column5: Lake Charles and Bossier City. It is the largest city in Jefferson Parish and the largest incorporated suburban city of New Orleans. The population was 66

column1: Originally inhabited by the Tchoupitoulas Indians
column2: the area along the Mississippi River was the first land in the New Orleans Metropolitan Area on which Europeans set foot. René-Robert Cavelier
column3: Sieur de La Salle landed there in 1682. In 1855
column4: Kenner was founded by Minor Kenner on land that consisted of three plantation properties that had been purchased by the Kenner family. At the time
column5: all land north of what is now Airline Highway was swampland.

column3: "Gypsy" Jem Mace defeated Tom Allen for the heavyweight championship of the bare-knuckle boxing era; a monument marks the spot near the river end of Williams Boulevard.

column2: a New Orleans streetcar line operated between New Orleans and Kenner. The line ran between the intersection of Rampart and Canal in New Orleans and the intersection of Williams Blvd and Jefferson Hwy in Kenner.

column1: Kenner's growth began in the late 1950s when developers began subdividing
column2: draining and filling the swampland in the northern half of the city.  During the 1960s
column3: the construction of Interstate 10 and improvements to Veterans Memorial Highway aided the rapid development of Kenner as a suburb of New Orleans.

column2: Pan Am Flight 759 crashed in a residential area of Kenner when a microburst forced it down. Eight people on the ground were killed
column3: as were all 145 people aboard the aircraft. Six houses were completely destroyed and five more substantially damaged.

Mayor E. Ben Zahn III circulated a memo banning the use of Nike products or the Nike logo "for use or delivery to any City of Kenner Recreating facility" ostensibly as a reaction to the decision by Nike to feature Colin Kaepernick in its advertising after his decision to kneel during the playing of the US national anthem at NFL games to protest inequality and police brutality. On September 12
column4: Mayor Zahn reversed the ban after political and legal criticism
column5: stating that it "placed Kenner in a false and unflattering light on the national stage."

column2: Hispanics and Latinos made up 22% of Kenner's population. Of the 20 U.S. Census Bureau tracts in Kenner
column3: 12 of them have Hispanic populations of 15% or more. One of those census tracts has the highest number of Hispanic and Latino people in all of Louisiana. By 2011
column4: many business catering to Hispanics and Latinos had opened in Kenner.

column1: A portion of north Kenner is called "Little Honduras." Kenner's Hispanic Resource Center offers English as a second language classes and after school programs.
Kenner is home to the following:
A. J. Muss Bertolino Playground – The playground includes Muss Bertolino Stadium that is used for high school football games
column2: lacrosse
column3: soccer and includes a running track. Muss Bertolino Gymnasium used for basketball and volleyball is also located in the playground along with a baseball park.

column1: Chateau Golf and Country Club — one of only three golf courses located in East Jefferson (the East Bank of Jefferson Parish).

Coconut Beach Volleyball Complex - 22 court sand volleyball complex located just south of the Pontchartrain Center in Laketown. It is the largest man-made sand complex in the United States. Before opening in Kenner
column2: Coconut Beach existed for 25 years in the West End neighborhood of New Orleans before the site was appropriated for an Army Corps of Engineers flood control project.

column1: The current mayor of Kenner is former Jefferson Parish councilman E. Ben Zahn III.
Kenner is represented in the Louisiana House of Representatives by the Republican attorney Tom Willmott. The state senator is Republican Danny Martiny
column2: a former state House member. Martiny's predecessor in the House is Kernan "Skip" Hand
column3: a retired district court judge from Kenner. Martiny's predecessor in the state Senate
column5: also resides in Kenner. Kenner is part of Louisiana's 1st Congressional district
column6: presently represented in the U.S. House by Steve Scalise.

column1: The United States Postal Service operates two post offices. They are the Kenner Post Office and the North Kenner Post Office.
At one time L'Express Airlines had its headquarters in Kenner.

column1: The Kenner Star is Kenner's free monthly community newspaper. Kenner is served primarily by New Orleans-based media outlets.
